CO-FLUAMPICIL

PENICILLINS

  • Pregnancy

Indications and doses

Mixed infections involving beta-lactamase-producing staphylococci,

By intramuscular injection or by slow intravenous injection or by intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    250/250 mg every 6 hours.
  • For adults
    250/250 mg every 6 hours.
  • For children 1 month–9 years
    125/125 mg every 6 hours.
  • For children 10–17 years
    250/250 mg every 6 hours.

Severe mixed infections involving beta-lactamase-producing staphylococci,

By intramuscular injection or by slow intravenous injection or by intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    500/500 mg every 6 hours.
  • For adults
    500/500 mg every 6 hours.
  • For children 1 month–9 years
    250/250 mg every 6 hours.
  • For children 10–17 years
    500/500 mg every 6 hours.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Not known to be harmful.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Use with caution.

Advice regarding renal impairment

In adults

Reduce dose if eGFR less than 10 mL/minute/1.73 m2; rashes more common.

In children

Reduce dose or frequency if estimated glomerular filtration rate less than 10 mL/minute/1.73 m2; rashes more common.

With intravenous use

Accumulation of electrolytes contained in parenteral preparations can occur in patients with renal failure.

Known side effects

General side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: Gastro-intestinal disturbances, nausea, vomiting,

veryRare: Cholestatic jaundice, hepatitis,

Rash

If rash occurs, discontinue treatment.

Directions for administration

With intravenous use in adults

For intravenous infusion (Magnapen ), give intermittently in Glucose 5% or Sodium chloride 0.9%. Reconstituted solutions diluted and given without delay; suggested volume 100 mL given over 30–60 minutes.

Via drip tubing in Glucose 5% or Sodium chloride 0.9%.

Important safety information

Hepatic disorders

Cholestatic jaundice and hepatitis may occur very rarely, up to two months after treatment with flucloxacillin has been stopped. Administration for more than 2 weeks and increasing age are risk factors. Healthcare professionals are reminded that:

  • flucloxacillin should not be used in patients with a history of hepatic dysfunction associated with flucloxacillin;
  • flucloxacillin should be used with caution in patients with hepatic impairment;
  • careful enquiry should be made about hypersensitivity reactions to beta-lactam antibacterials.

Cautions regarding administration

  • Acute lymphocytic leukaemia (increased risk of erythematous rashes)
  • chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (increased risk of erythematous rashes)
  • cytomegalovirus infection (increased risk of erythematous rashes)
  • glandular fever (erythematous rashes common)
  • With intravenous use: accumulation of electrolytes contained in parenteral preparations can occur with high doses
  • With intravenous use: risk of kernicterus in jaundiced neonates when high doses given parenterally in neonates

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

Dose expressed as a combination of equal parts by mass of flucloxacillin and ampicillin.

Effect on laboratory tests

False-positive urinary glucose (if tested for reducing substances).

Prepared medicinal forms of CO-FLUAMPICIL

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Capsule
Oral suspension
Powder for solution for injection
